articles.title: How to use...
articles.contents:
… The database pages
This database provides an overview of the available core variables
related to youth and child wellbeing measures. It should be viewed as an
entry point for research on this topic.
More detailed information on the variables, including detailed
response categories and original variable names can be found in
 this Excel file.
For the most detailed level of information, the original survey
documentation should be consulted. To simplify the search, the survey
names are highlighted with links to surveys’ documentation entry pages
if possible.
… The harmonisation pages
Harmonisation can be a useful method for researchers who wish to
compile similar measures collected by separate studies. In the
harmonisation pages of this database,
we provide instruction for retrospective (ex-post) harmonisation of
existing data sources in a selection of the core child wellbeing
measures.

articles.title: Variable harmonization
articles.contents:
Set-up
The following packages are necessary for importing, managing, and
harmonization of data:


library(haven)  # Import foreign statistical formats
library(labelled)  # Functions to manipulate variable labels, value labels and missing values
library(tidyverse)  # Suite of packages for data management
library(questionr)  # Helps with frequency tables
library(writexl)  # Export to Excel
library(readxl)  # Importing from Excel


Data import
The first task is to import the data. At this time, only the relevant
variable is imported. Before being finalized, the technical (eg.
weights, identifiers) and demographic variables must be added. Where
possible, the SPSS file format is preferred, since it comes with
variable and value labels that are easy to extract.


# British Household Panel Study (BHPS)  
setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/Source Surveys Data & Documentation/British Household Panel Study (BHPS)/SPSS BHPS Wave 1-18/UKDA-5151-spss/spss/spss19")

Prepare harmonization
variables
The next stage is the preparation of the variables for harmonization.
In this step, we create a codebook with a list of source variable names,
value labels, any additional info (eg. categorical vs continuous
coding), and the source data. We first need a function that will extract
the information we need and then combine the information together into a
list.


create_codebook <- function(data) {
  var_labels <- data.frame(cbind(names(var_label(data)), do.call(rbind, var_label(data)))) %>%
    rename(varname = X1, varlabel = X2)
  freqs <- lapply(data, function(x) { return(questionr::freq(x)) }) %>%
    keep(function(x) nrow(x) < 1000) %>%
    do.call(rbind, .) %>% 
    tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "varname_value") %>%
    mutate(varname = gsub("(.+?)(\\..*)", "\\1", varname_value),
           value = gsub("^[^.]*.","",varname_value)) %>%
    group_by(varname) %>%
    mutate(npos = row_number(),
           value_n = paste(value, n, sep = ": ")) %>%
    select(varname, value_n, npos) %>%
    spread(npos, value_n) %>%
    mutate_at(vars(-varname), list(~ifelse(is.na(.), "", .))) %>%  # This line (funs()) needs to be updated
    unite("valfreqs", c(2:ncol(.)), sep = "\n") %>%
    mutate(valfreqs = sub("\\s+$", "", valfreqs))
  full_join(var_labels, freqs, by = "varname")
}

  mutate(table_name = "dji_2003")


The individual codebooks can then be combined together and exported
to Excel.


codebook_all <- bind_rows(
    codebook_bhps_1994, codebook_bhps_1995, codebook_bhps_1996, codebook_bhps_1997, 
    codebook_bhps_1998, codebook_bhps_1999, codebook_bhps_2000, codebook_bhps_2001,
    codebook_bhps_2002, codebook_bhps_2003, codebook_bhps_2004, codebook_bhps_2005,
    codebook_bhps_2006, codebook_bhps_2007, codebook_bhps_2008,
    codebook_us_2009, codebook_us_2010, codebook_us_2011, codebook_us_2012,
    codebook_us_2013, codebook_us_2014, codebook_us_2015, codebook_us_2016,
    codebook_us_2017, codebook_us_2018, codebook_cw_2012_8, codebook_cw_2012_10, 
    codebook_cw_2012_12, codebook_cw_2014_8, codebook_cw_2014_10, codebook_cw_2014_12,
    codebook_cw_2019_10, codebook_cw_2019_12, codebook_mcs_2006, codebook_mcs_2008, 
    codebook_mcs_2008p, codebook_mcs_2012, codebook_mcs_2015,
    codebook_ns_2004a, codebook_ns_2004b, codebook_ns_2005a, codebook_ns_2005b,
    codebook_ns_2006a, codebook_ns_2006b, codebook_hsbc_2002, codebook_dji_2003
                          ) %>%
  mutate(target_var = NA)  
setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/D4.3-Harmonization/2_Education/ch_EDsati_1")
write_xlsx(codebook_all, "ch_EDsati_1_codebook.xlsx")


The codebook can now be examined. Each row in the Excel file
corresponds to one dataset. The following fields are displayed in the
columns:
varname is the name of the variable in the original
dataset
varlabel is the label of the variable in the original
dataset
valfreqs is the frequency for each value in the
original dataset
table_name is the abbreviated name of of the original
dataset
The table looks like this:


rmarkdown::paged_table(codebook_all)




Create a crosswalk table
The next step is to map the input values to target values using a
so-called crosswalk table. Start by importing the Excel table created in
the previous step:


setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/D4.3-Harmonization/2_Education/ch_EDsati_1")
cb <- read_xlsx("ch_EDsati_1_codebook.xlsx")

create_cwt <- function(data) {
  var_labels <- data.frame(cbind(names(var_label(data)), do.call(rbind, var_label(data)))) %>%
    rename(varname = X1, varlabel = X2)
  freqs_cwt <- lapply(data, function(x) { return(questionr::freq(x)) }) %>%
    keep(function(x) nrow(x) < 1000) %>%
    do.call(rbind, .) %>% 
    tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "varname_value") %>%
    mutate(varname = gsub("(.+?)(\\..*)", "\\1", varname_value),
           value = gsub("^[^.]*.","",varname_value),
           value_code = sub(".*\\[(.+)\\].*", "\\1", varname_value, perl = TRUE),
           value_code = ifelse(str_sub(varname_value, -2, -1) == "NA", "NA", value_code),
           value_code = ifelse(gsub(" ", "", fixed = TRUE, varname_value) == varname_value, 
                               gsub("^[^.]*.","",varname_value), value_code)) %>%
    group_by(varname) %>%
    mutate(npos = row_number(),
           value_n = paste(value, n, sep = ": ")) %>%
    select(npos, varname, value_n, value, value_code)
  
  full_join(var_labels, freqs_cwt, by = "varname")
}

data_tables <- c("BHPS_1994", "BHPS_1995", "BHPS_1996", "BHPS_1997",
                 "BHPS_1998", "BHPS_1999", "BHPS_2000", "BHPS_2001",
                 "BHPS_2002", "BHPS_2003", "BHPS_2004", "BHPS_2005",
                 "BHPS_2006", "BHPS_2007", "BHPS_2008", 
                 "us_2009", "us_2010", "us_2011", "us_2012", "us_2013", 
                 "us_2014", "us_2015", "us_2016", "us_2017", "us_2018",
                 "cw_2012_8", "cw_2012_10", "cw_2012_12", 
                 "cw_2014_8", "cw_2014_10", "cw_2014_12", "cw_2019_10", "cw_2019_12", 
                 "mcs_2006", "mcs_2008", "mcs_2008p", "mcs_2012", "mcs_2015",
                 "ns_2004a", "ns_2004b", "ns_2005a", "ns_2005b",
                 "ns_2006a", "ns_2006b", "hsbc_2002", "dji_2003")
cwt_all <- list()

for (i in (1:length(data_tables))) {
  table_name_input <- data_tables[i]
  varnames <- cb$varname[cb$table_name == table_name_input]
  cwt_all[[i]] <- eval(parse(text = tolower(table_name_input))) %>%
    select(varnames) %>%
    create_cwt() %>%
    mutate(table_name = table_name_input)
}

cwt_all <- do.call(rbind, cwt_all) 

cwt_all %>%
  select(-varlabel) %>%
  left_join(cb, by = c("varname", "table_name")) %>%
  mutate(target_value = NA) %>%
  select(table_name, target_var,
         varname, varlabel, starts_with("c_"),
         value_n, value_code, target_value) %>%
  write_xlsx(., "cwt_all.xlsx")


We now have a new table that shows the values of the original
variables as well as an empty column that can be used to map on the new
variable values


rmarkdown::paged_table(cwt_all)




Harmonization


setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/D4.3-Harmonization/2_Education/ch_EDsati_1")
cwt_all1 <- readxl::read_xlsx("cwt_all.xlsx")

survey_files <- plyr::rbind.fill(bhps_1994, bhps_1995, bhps_1996, bhps_1997, bhps_1998, 
                      bhps_1999, bhps_2000, bhps_2001, bhps_2002, bhps_2003, 
                      bhps_2004, bhps_2005,  bhps_2006, bhps_2007, bhps_2008, 
                      us_2009, us_2010, us_2011, us_2012, us_2013, us_2014, us_2015, 
                      us_2016, us_2017, cw_2012_8, cw_2012_10, cw_2012_12, 
                      cw_2014_8, cw_2014_10, cw_2014_12, cw_2019_10, 
                      cw_2019_12, mcs_2006, mcs_2008, mcs_2008p, mcs_2012, mcs_2015,
                      ns_2004a, ns_2004b, ns_2005a, ns_2005b, ns_2006a, ns_2006b,
                      hsbc_2002, dji_2003
                      )
survey_files <- survey_files %>%
  mutate(ch_EDsati_1=replace(ch_EDsati_1, which(ch_EDsati_1<0L), NA)) %>%
  group_by(table_name) %>%
  mutate(ch_EDsati_1_harm = round(plotrix::rescale(ch_EDsati_1, c(1,11))))

saveRDS(survey_files, file="ch_EDsati_1_harm.Rds")

df <- readRDS("ch_EDsati_1_harm.Rds")

articles.title: Variable harmonization
articles.description: Children's perceptions of safety in their neighbourhood
articles.contents:
Set-up
The following packages are necessary for importing, managing, and
harmonization of data:


library(haven)  # Import foreign statistical formats
library(labelled)  # Functions to manipulate variable labels, value labels and missing values
library(tidyverse)  # Suite of packages for data management
library(questionr)  # Helps with frequency tables
library(writexl)  # Export to Excel
library(readxl)  # Importing from Excel


Data import
The first task is to import the data. At this time, only the relevant
variable is imported. Before being finalized, the technical (eg.
weights, identifiers) and demographic variables must be added. Where
possible, the SPSS file format is preferred, since it comes with
variable and value labels that are easy to extract.

articles.title: Child Wellbeing Variable Database
articles.contents:
We have organized related measures into categories based on a
framework developed by the OECD. This framework takes a holistic
approach designed to aid evidence-based policy development. They trace
measures in outcomes (material, physical health, social, emotional,
cultural, cognitive, and educational) children’s activities,
relationships, and behaviours (family, health, social, leisure, civil,
learning, and digital), children’s settings and environments (family,
home, school, community), and public policy conditions (family, housing,
health, educational and environmental policies). These are adapted by
Schölmerich and his colleagues (Schölmerich, Agache, and Leyendecker
2015) into the following categories which we use to organize
the measurement items:
 Material wellbeing
 Education  Health and safety
 Family and environment
 Risk behaviour and lifestyle
 Subjective
wellbeing



Schölmerich, Axel, Alexandru Agache, and Birgit Leyendecker. 2015.
“Child Well-Being: Indicators and Measurement.” In
Promoting Psychological Well-Being in Children and Families,
123–34. Springer.

articles.title: Education
articles.contents:
Contents
Satisfaction with
education
Satisfaction with Teacher
Learning difficulties

The educational and cognitive development are central aspects of a
child’s wellbeing. Children begin learning from birth and continue to
expand their skills, knowledge, and capabilities as they progress
through early childhood education, into the school system and beyond.
Peer relations, relations with teachers and school administration, and
family involvement all influence the educational experience of children
playing an important role in their wellbeing in childhood and adulthood
as individuals enter the labour force. Therefore, measuring aspects of
the educational experience of children is important to determining their
overall wellbeing.

articles.title: Family and environment
articles.contents:
Contents
Local neighbourhood:
Perception of safety
Socialising with friends
Number of close friends
Positive family
environment

Children need to feel safe and nurtured in their home environment.
Throughout the course of childhood, children develop the ability to form
positive relationships with peers and adults and to cope with
adversities or set-backs they might encounter, thanks to the resources
available in the family, at school, in friendships networks or in the
community environment. Missing out on opportunities to develop strong
social-emotional skills serves children a disadvantage as young adults
in terms of various well-being outcomes.

articles.title: Harmonization
articles.description: Guidelines for harmonizing child wellbeing variables
articles.contents:
Harmonization
Ex-post (or retrospective) harmonization procedures are applied to
already collected data to improve comparability and inferential
equivalence of measures gathered by different source studies. Since
there is little prior knowledge on comparative measurements for the
well-being of children and young people, micro-data from a number of key
child well-being surveys in Europe have been prepared for comparative
analysis by a carefully conducted and documented ex-post harmonization
process and the outcomes examined thoroughly for their performance in
terms of measurement equivalence (where possible), and possible losses
of reliability and validity as compared to the source data. This will
increase the understanding of the relative (dis-) advantages of
particular, alternative forms of measuring the same concepts in the
comparative setting. Below we provide guidelines for conducting the
harmonization on the key variables using
R .
The harmonization work flow is fairly straightforward as shown in the
figure below. For each concept we wish to harmonize, we gather the
relevant variable from the available datasets, map the values together,
and then aggregate them into a harmonized vector including individual
case identifiers so that multiple harmonized variables can be joined
together and analyzed.




Figure 1: Harmonization work flow

articles.title: Health
articles.contents:
Contents
General
Health
Exercise and physical
activity

Children’s physical health is a major component of well-being from
early life through to adolescence and is a key determinant of health
status in later adult life. Having good physical health during childhood
has been linked to higher levels of educational attainment and better
employment and economic outcomes later in life; it also lays the
foundation for greater psychological well-being and life satisfaction.
By contrast, adverse health events during childhood can have
long-lasting effects on later adult health and other key outcomes, such
as employment status and earnings.

articles.title: Child Wellbeing Variable Database
articles.description: To assist researchers, policy makers, and others interested in child wellbeing, we have prepared a central database listing child and youth wellbeing measures commonly used in key longitudinal and cross-sectional comparative surveys in Europe organized by literature-based core concepts.
articles.contents:
There has been an increasing number of child well-being surveys at
national and cross-European levels. From a research point of view, the
value of such data increases dramatically if the data originally
collected for national research become available for truly comparative
analyses. On these pages, we list the relevant datasets and provide
descriptions of the datasets and variables that are available for
researchers and policy makers who wish to better understand child
wellbeing.
Beyond the provision of information on variables, we have been
working on the harmonisation of individual variables. Under the
Harmonisation tab we provide a detailed
guide through the harmonisation process using the freely available
statistical software R.
Researchers have taken various approaches to categorize child
wellbeing measures, often depending upon the focus of the research.
Broadly, most frameworks are developed to make or inform policy-oriented
recommendations for children and families or to better understand the
underlying causes and consequences of child wellbeing (Pollock et al. 2018).



Pollock, Gary, Jessica Ozan, Haridhan Goswami, Gwyther Rees, and Anita
Stasulane. 2018. Measuring Youth Well-Being: How a Pan-European
Longitudinal Survey Can Improve Policy. Children’s Well-Being:
Indicators and Research. Springer International Publishing.

articles.title: Material Wellbeing
articles.contents:
Contents
Household
Income
Worries over family
finances
Access to reading
material in the home
Number of rooms in the
household
Household electronic
devices

Economic conditions play an important role in the well-being of
Children. Evidence shows that children raised in economically
disadvantaged families begin school behind peer and are negatively
affected by this throughout their lives. Children’s material living
standards are central to child wellbeing. For children, having access to
basic material goods and activities is important in and of itself and is
further related to other aspects of their lives.

articles.title: Variable harmonization
articles.contents:
Set-up
The following packages are necessary for importing, managing, and
harmonization of data:


library(haven)  # Import foreign statistical formats
library(labelled)  # Functions to manipulate variable labels, value labels and missing values
library(tidyverse)  # Suite of packages for data management
library(questionr)  # Helps with frequency tables
library(writexl)  # Export to Excel
library(readxl)  # Importing from Excel


Data import
The first task is to import the data. At this time, only the relevant
variable is imported. Before being finalized, the technical (eg.
weights, identifiers) and demographic variables must be added. Where
possible, the SPSS file format is preferred, since it comes with
variable and value labels that are easy to extract.


# British Household Panel Study (BHPS)  
setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/Source Surveys Data & Documentation/British Household Panel Study (BHPS)/SPSS BHPS Wave 1-18/UKDA-5151-spss/spss/spss19")
bhps_1994 <- read_sav("./bhps_w4/dhhresp.sav", col_select=c("dfihhyr", "dhid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = dfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = dhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_1994")
bhps_1995 <- read_sav("./bhps_w5/ehhresp.sav", col_select=c("efihhyr", "ehid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = efihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = ehid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_1995")
bhps_1996 <- read_sav("./bhps_w6/fhhresp.sav", col_select=c("ffihhyr", "fhid"), user_na=FALSE)  %>%
  rename_with(.cols = ffihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = fhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_1996")
bhps_1997 <- read_sav("./bhps_w7/ghhresp.sav", col_select=c("gfihhyr", "ghid"), user_na=FALSE)  %>%
  rename_with(.cols = gfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = ghid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_1997")
bhps_1998 <- read_sav("./bhps_w8/hhhresp.sav", col_select=c("hfihhyr", "hhid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = hfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = hhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_1998")
bhps_1999 <- read_sav("./bhps_w9/ihhresp.sav", col_select=c("ifihhyr", "ihid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = ifihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = ihid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_1999")
bhps_2000 <- read_sav("./bhps_w10/jhhresp.sav", col_select=c("jfihhyr", "jhid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = jfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = jhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2000")
bhps_2001 <- read_sav("./bhps_w11/khhresp.sav", col_select=c("kfihhyr", "khid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = kfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = khid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2001")
bhps_2002 <- read_sav("./bhps_w12/lhhresp.sav", col_select=c("lfihhyr", "lhid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = lfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = lhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2002")
bhps_2003 <- read_sav("./bhps_w13/mhhresp.sav", col_select=c("mfihhyr", "mhid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = mfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = mhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2003")
bhps_2004 <- read_sav("./bhps_w14/nhhresp.sav", col_select=c("nfihhyr", "nhid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = nfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = nhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2004")
bhps_2005 <- read_sav("./bhps_w15/ohhresp.sav", col_select=c("ofihhyr", "ohid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = ofihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = ohid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2005")
bhps_2006 <- read_sav("./bhps_w16/phhresp.sav", col_select=c("pfihhyr", "phid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = pfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = phid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2006")
bhps_2007 <- read_sav("./bhps_w17/qhhresp.sav", col_select=c("qfihhyr", "qhid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = qfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = qhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2007")
bhps_2008 <- read_sav("./bhps_w18/rhhresp.sav", col_select=c("rfihhyr", "rhid"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = rfihhyr, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = rhid, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "bhps_2008")


# Understanding Society (US)
setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/Source Surveys Data & Documentation/Understanding Society (US)/spss/UKDA-6614-spss/spss/spss25")
us_2009 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w1/a_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("a_fihhmngrs_dv", "a_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = a_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = a_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2009")
us_2010 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w2/b_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("b_fihhmngrs_dv", "b_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = b_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = b_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2010")
us_2011 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w3/c_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("c_fihhmngrs_dv", "c_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = c_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = c_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2011")
us_2012 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w4/d_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("d_fihhmngrs_dv", "d_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = d_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = d_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2012")
us_2013 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w5/e_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("e_fihhmngrs_dv", "e_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = e_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = e_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2013")
us_2014 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w6/f_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("f_fihhmngrs_dv", "f_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = f_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = f_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2014")
us_2015 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w7/g_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("g_fihhmngrs_dv", "g_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = g_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = g_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2015")
us_2016 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w8/h_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("h_fihhmngrs_dv", "h_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = h_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = h_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2016")
us_2017 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w9/i_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("i_fihhmngrs_dv", "i_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = i_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = i_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2017")
us_2018 <- read_sav("./ukhls_w10/j_hhresp.sav", col_select=c("j_fihhmngrs_dv", "j_hidp"), user_na=FALSE) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = j_fihhmngrs_dv, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = j_hidp, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "us_2018")



# Millenium Cohort Survey
setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/Source Surveys Data & Documentation/Millenium Cohort Study (MCS)")
# Household and person identifier (no unique identifier in original data)
mcs_2004 <- read_stata("./Data & Documentation (Wave 2 - 2004 - 3 Years Old)/stata/stata13/mcs2_parent_interview.dta", col_select=c("BPGROA00", "MCSID", "BPNUM00")) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = BPGROA00, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  mutate(ID=paste0(MCSID, BPNUM00)) %>%
  mutate(table_name = "mcs_2004") %>%
  select(-c(MCSID, BPNUM00))
# Missing income info in this wave
# mcs_2006 <- read_stata("./Data & Documentation (Wave 3 - 2006 - 5 Years Old)/stata/stata13/mcs3_parent_interview.dta", col_select=c("CPGROA00", "MCSID", "CPNUM00")) %>%
#   rename_with(.cols = CPGROA00, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
#   mutate(ID=paste0(MCSID, CPNUM00)) %>%
#   mutate(table_name = "mcs_2006") %>%
#   select(-c(MCSID, CPNUM00))
mcs_2008 <- read_dta("./Data & Documentation (Wave 4 - 2008 - 7 Years Old)/stata/stata13/mcs4_parent_interview.dta", col_select=c("DPGROA00", "MCSID", "DPNUM00")) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = DPGROA00, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  mutate(ID=paste0(MCSID, DPNUM00)) %>%
  mutate(table_name = "mcs_2008p") %>%
  select(-c(MCSID, DPNUM00))
mcs_2012 <- read_dta("./Data & Documentation (Wave 5 - 2012 - 11 Years Old)/stata/stata13/mcs5_parent_interview.dta", col_select=c("EPGROA00", "MCSID", "EPNUM00")) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = EPGROA00, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  mutate(ID=paste0("MCSID", "EPNUM00")) %>%
  mutate(table_name = "mcs_2012") %>%
  select(-c(MCSID, EPNUM00))
mcs_2015 <- read_dta("./Data & Documentation (Wave 6 - 2015 - 14 Years Old)/stata/stata13/mcs6_parent_interview.dta", col_select=c("FPGROA00", "MCSID", "FPNUM00")) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = FPGROA00, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  mutate(ID=paste0("MCSID", "FPNUM00")) %>%
  mutate(table_name = "mcs_2015") %>%
  select(-c(MCSID, FPNUM00))

# Next Steps (LYPSE)
setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/Source Surveys Data & Documentation/Next Steps (LYPSE)/Data & Documentation Next Steps (LYPSE (Wave 1-8) (SPSS))/UKDA-5545-spss/spss/spss25/eul")
ns_2004 <- read_sav("./wave_one_lsype_family_background_2020.sav", col_select = c("W1inc2estMP", "NSID")) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = W1inc2estMP, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%  
  rename_with(.cols = NSID, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "ns_2004")
ns_2005 <- read_sav("./wave_two_lsype_family_background_2020.sav", col_select = c("W2Inc2estMP", "NSID")) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = W2Inc2estMP, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = NSID, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "ns_2005")
#ns_2006 <- read_sav("./wave_three_lsype_family_background_2020.sav", col_select = c("W3incestMP", "NSID")) %>%
#  rename_with(.cols = W3incestMP, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
#  rename_with(.cols = NSID, ~"ID") %>%
#  mutate(table_name = "ns_2006")
#ns_2007 <- read_sav("./wave_four_lsype_family_background_2020.sav", col_select = c("W4Inc1EstMP", "NSID")) %>%
#  rename_with(.cols = W4Inc1EstMP, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
#  rename_with(.cols = NSID, ~"ID") %>%
#  mutate(table_name = "ns_2007")

# DJI
setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/Source Surveys Data & Documentation/Deutsches Jugendinstitut Jugendsurvey (DJI)/Data")
dji_1997 <- read_dta("ZA3298.dta", col_select=c("JS53", "JF00_1")) %>%
  mutate(JS53 = replace(JS53, which(JS53>94L), NA)) %>%
  rename_with(.cols = JS53, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
  rename_with(.cols = JF00_1, ~"ID") %>%
  mutate(table_name = "dji_1997")
## Potentially return to this. The response cats are in letters...?
# dji_2003 <- read_dta("ZA5187.dta", col_select=c("J505T", "lfd")) %>%
#   mutate(JS53 = replace(JS53, which(JS53>94L), NA)) %>%
#   rename_with(.cols = J505T, ~"pa_MWinco_1") %>%
#   rename_with(.cols = lfd, ~"ID") %>%
#   mutate(table_name = "dji_2003")


Harmonization
First we bring the files together


survey_files <- plyr::rbind.fill(bhps_1994, bhps_1995, bhps_1996, bhps_1997, bhps_1998, 
                                 bhps_1999, bhps_2000, bhps_2001, bhps_2002, bhps_2003, 
                                 bhps_2004, bhps_2005,  bhps_2006, bhps_2007, bhps_2008, 
                                 us_2009, us_2010, us_2011, us_2012, us_2013, us_2014, us_2015, 
                                 us_2016, us_2017, mcs_2008, mcs_2012, mcs_2015, 
                                 ns_2004, dji_1997)


Because household income is a quantitative variable, we will divide
the incomes into country-specific deciles.


# Scale to deciles
survey_files <- survey_files %>%
  mutate(pa_MWinco_1=replace(pa_MWinco_1, which(pa_MWinco_1<0L), NA)) %>%
  group_by(table_name) %>%
  mutate(pa_MWinco_1_harm = gtools::quantcut(pa_MWinco_1, q=10, na.rm=TRUE, labels=FALSE))


setwd("I:/Team_IntUm/COORDINATE/D4.3-Harmonization/1_Material/pa_MWinco_1")
saveRDS(survey_files, file="pa_MWinco_1_harm.Rds")

df <- readRDS("pa_MWinco_1_harm.Rds")

articles.title: Variable harmonization
articles.contents:
Set-up
The following packages are necessary for importing, managing, and
harmonization of data:


library(haven)  # Import foreign statistical formats
library(labelled)  # Functions to manipulate variable labels, value labels and missing values
library(tidyverse)  # Suite of packages for data management
library(questionr)  # Helps with frequency tables
library(writexl)  # Export to Excel
library(readxl)  # Importing from Excel


Data import
The first task is to import the data. At this time, only the relevant
variable is imported. Before being finalized, the technical (eg.
weights, identifiers) and demographic variables must be added. Where
possible, the SPSS file format is preferred, since it comes with
variable and value labels that are easy to extract.

articles.title: Risk behaviour and lifestyle
articles.contents:
Contents
Tobacco use
Eating
habits
Out of school activities
Drug use

Children’s social and emotional well-being can be compromised by risk
factors present in the environments within which they interact. The
presence of conflict between family members or domestic violence deeply
affect the emotional and affective well-being of children. School can be
a place where bullying occurs, or where children struggle to fit in.
Deprived neighbourhoods where poverty and crime are more common expose
children to higher risks and reduce their sense of safety. The absence
of recreational facilities and green spaces leave children without
adequate places to play safely and hang around with friends.

articles.title: Subjective wellbeing
articles.contents:
Contents
Happiness
Victim of
Bullying

Life satisfaction assessments rely on a more fundamental judgment
about children’s satisfaction with their life taken as a whole, or by
just focusing on separate areas of life such as family, school or social
relationships. Children’s states of mental health determine how well
they can manage the different kinds of emotions, affects and feelings
that life events arouse, which at times can be intense and varied in
nature. One way to measure mental health is to ask about subjective life
evaluations, i.e. how happy one thinks he or she is, and how one feels
about him or herself and life in general. This is usually possible from
middle childhood onwards. Then it is common to ask children how they are
feeling at a particular point in time i.e. core affect. This type of
feeling varies over time and does not have a beginning nor an end, and
may not necessarily be directed at anything. Often it can be feeling
happy, or relaxed, or satisfied, or in a calm state or full of
energy.

is teased repeatedly in a way he or she does not like or when he or she

students of about the same strength or power argue or fight. It is also
